channel.title: Interesting Apps on juri.strumpflohner
channel.description: Recent content in Interesting Apps on juri.strumpflohner

item.title: Will I really Miss Google Reader??
item.description: I guess you probably heard the latest announcements about the Google Reader shutdown. I heard about it already about half a year ago I guess, but didn’t want to believe initially.

item.title: Setting up my Developer Machine
item.description: Developers need to have fast machines! Today I just returned from a week of holidays at Kos (Greece). Amazing! So you might imagine that returning to work is usually less pleasant ;), but that changed when I opened Outlook and saw the email from our systems department that my new developer machine setup was ready.

item.title: Gist: A Suitable Tool For Collaborative Online Code Reviews?
item.description: Doing code reviews is an extremely useful practice where you can learn a ton of things. Prerequisite: being open-minded and ready to share your code, accept and learn from criticism ;).

item.title: More Than Just Synching - Dropbox
item.description: You know Dropbox, right (if not, head on to get it here)? I totally love that tool. I mean, you nearly don't notice its presence and actually that's what I love so much.

item.title: Presentation: Dropbox Startup Lessons Learned
item.description: An interesting presentation by the Dropbox founder Drew Houston about Dropbox startup lessons learned. Also if you don't plan to create any startup it is still interesting to see some of the strategies that have been applied and which finally made Dropbox as successful as it is - in a market which btw already seemed to be saturated.

item.title: Tired to Manually Enter Wifi Network Configurations into your Android Phone??
item.description: Today a rather non-programming-related blog post :) . You probably encountered already the issue of configuring your Wifi access to your home or work wireless system.

item.title: Reloaded: Clean up your folder. For OSX
item.description: When downloading files from the web I usually have a predefined folder where all the downloads from my different browsers are stored. It doesn't take long till that folder grows to quite a remarkable size.

item.title: Google Wave...a first comment
item.description: I've now played a bit around with Google Wave for nearly two weeks now and it's quite cool. The real-time collaborative editing is just amazing, as you can also see in the dozen of demonstration videos which are around the web already.

item.title: Annotation tools for the Mac
item.description: When you create scientific reports or you just prepare for exams you usually have to go over a whole bunch of papers, lecture notes and websites.

item.title: New equation editor makes GDocs even more usable!!
item.description: I always liked the idea of having a office-like suite on the web. I already used Writely for taking quick notes or just short documents, already before it was acquired by Google and merged - together with Google Spreadsheets - to the Google Documents service.

item.title: Dropbox iPhone app will soon be released!
item.description: The official Dropbox blog announced that they submitted their iPhone app for approval. Just some of the features they mentioned: Access your Dropbox on the go -  All the contents of your Dropbox are available for viewing.

item.title: Firefox 3.5
item.description: Here's a short video of the director of the Firefox development team showing the new features in version 3.5 which should be available soon (these days actually).

item.title: QSB - Google Quick Search bar for the Mac
item.description: And voila, the 1st Mac-related post :) Just a quick one, I have to continue with my studies so.. When I switched over to the Mac (2 weeks ago now) I started to get productive as quick as possible (due to my exams).

item.title: Google Wave - Collaboration et excellence
item.description: Some days ago I just quickly scrolled over my Google Reader friends' items and saw Manfred's blog entry about Google Wave. It kept my attention since I didn't yet hear anything about that new Google product.

item.title: Dropbox - Sharing, synching and backup has never been so easy
item.description: I wanted to write this post already for a longer time, actually I had it (between my other approx. 30 not yet finished posts) in the draft folder.

item.title: Use Firebug everywhere!
item.description: You're a web developer and you cannot live without Firebug? Understandable. Firebug provides such great facilities such as JavaScript debugging, direct content modification of CSS and HTML, DOM inspection and much more.

item.title: AJAX APIs Playground Ver. 2
item.description: Google announced the version 2 of the AJAX APIs Playground. As you probably know, Google provides you a simple way for managing (especially the versions) the most useful JavaScript libraries such as jQuery, Dojo, Prototype scriptaculus etc.

item.title: Google contacts and calendar sync
item.description: Google published a new service called Google Sync that allows to integrate the data on Gmail and GCalendar with mobile devices. The steps for activating the synchronization are indicated on the Google Sync page.

item.title: Do you also lie awake at night wondering...
item.description:
...what is 2 + 1, whether ABBA is a palindrome? :D Then you will have a solution now: The lego Turing machine!!
Too cool :) Here's the link to the according blog:

item.title: HowTo: synchronize Google Calendar with your iPhone
item.description: I'm sure you already tried this before. Well unfortunately there is no existing, pre-installed way for synchronizing your iPhone calendar with your Google Calendar. What you can do is to sync your Outlook calendars with your iPhone, either when attaching it to your Mac, PC or whatever (having iTunes installed of course :) , Apples strategy as usual) or over the Microsoft Exchange account (if you have one).

item.title: Discover: file management on the iPhone
item.description: As I've written already in this post I bought an iPhone and I'm really satisfied with it. The experience in browsing the web is really amazing.

item.title: Launchy available for Linux
item.description: Today I discovered that Launchy (my favorite key stroker) is now also available for Linux. I was able to install it with three commands.

item.title: Passpack - Manage your passwords the intelligent way
item.description: I don't know in which way you record your passwords and other sensitive data. The best way is of course to just remember them, and it may work quite well for a while, but once you get more passwords, you may forget them.

item.title: Lively - Google's answer to Second Live
item.description: Originally I wanted to finish a post I'm currently writing, but then I came across one mentioning Google's newest product. There have already been some rumors about a secret project at Google and now it's out.

item.title: Program icon search engines
item.description: When I create a new piece of software I usually also want to give them the appropriate look (from a style perspective). That's in my eyes also a main key point to make it successful and user-friendly.

item.title: Got a Dropbox account
item.description: I don't know whether you remember my post some time ago, about new services appearing on the web which offer you webspace for uploading files and sharing them with others.

item.title: Cuzillion - High performance web pages testing
item.description: I don't want to write much (I'm too lazy today :) ), but I just flew over my GReader feeds and disovered the following interesting post.

item.title: Finally, I got Google Docs offline access
item.description: I don't whether you've heared already something about Google Gears? Summarizing shortly it is the possibility of letting modern web ajax applications work offline. Sounds strange to you, letting an "

item.title: Twittering :)
item.description: Today I opened a new Twitter account. From time to time I got in touch with it and heared people being fascinated about the service.

item.title: Finally, a new GTalk version
item.description: I don't even remember for how long Gtalk hasn't experienced any update. While the Gmail Chat received the capability to be "invisible" and the GTalk Gadget version a "

item.title: Divshare, Dropbox and the still misterious GDrive
item.description: Recently several new online services cut its way to me over Google Reader. Those services offer the user a certain amount of "managed" webspace. "

item.title: How to open docx files??
item.description: First of all: I forgot my blog's "birthday" :D On the 9th february this blog here became 1 year old. My resum√© of 1 year of blogging?

item.title: Remember the milk
item.description: Did you hear about it?? Rememberthemilk is an online task tracking tool with a lot of cool and nice features which make it worth to place a post here.

item.title: Speed check: Test your broadband connection
item.description: I finally got a broadband internet connection at home :) For those who don't know it: I actually live on about 1,100 meters above see level and so I had to content myself with a normal 56K ISDN connection.

item.title: Never wanted to download a YouTube Video??
item.description: YouTube has become an enourmous platform of video information. You find everything from technical tutorials and speechs, music clips to nonsense stuff put by someone.

item.title: Creating simple backups with WinRAR
item.description: When I'm working on some code for a program I'm developing, I got into the habit of creating regular backups. That's quite useful, also when you're using a version control system (SVN, CVS,.

item.title: Finally syntax highlighting on my blog!!
item.description: Edit: Note that this blog post is obsolete as I switched both, my blog hosting provider as well as the syntax highlighting tool. This was actually a point which was somehow a thorn in my side.

item.title: Working for hours in front of the screen??
item.description: Then I maybe have a solution for you :) Actually a friend of mine (thanks Manfred ;) ) send me the link to a nice program that keeps track of your working hours in front of the screen.

item.title: Creating professional websites as non-professional person
item.description: Often people talk about "Web 2.0" which is not somehow a new version of the Web itself. The term just gives an already existing movement/change a name.

item.title: Google Earth | Sky
item.description: Some time ago I've read (I don't remember where) that NASA will cooperate with Google for integrating their large amount of space pictures and celestial maps into Google Earth.

item.title: Google Talk JavaScript Client
item.description: Today, while scrolling over my Google Reader entries, a headline from the Google Operating System blog (not an official Google blog) got my attention: "

item.title: Aodhan Cullen is the BusinessWeek Young Entrepreneur of the year
item.description: Probably you'll ask yourself now: Who is Aodhan Cullen...should I know him? Well, the word "StatCounter" will tell you for sure more...and if not...then it's worth to continue to read here.

item.title: Eclipse Europa is out
item.description:
Eclipse Europa is out!!!
What is Eclipse?? "Eclipse is an open source community whose projects are focused on building an open development platform comprised of extensible frameworks, tools and runtimes for building, deploying and managing software across the lifecycle.
